Taylor Brooks.Action: Uses pendulum and observes physical signs (sweaty palm, blushing) to detect lies, demonstrating keen perceptiveness and confidence.
Holds Lisa's hand firmly when she tries to escape, showing assertiveness and control in a social situation.
Attempts a risky solo climb up the outside of the building to reach friends, showing determination and a playful attempt to surprise an old lady by saying 'Boo!'
Responds with hostility to a man’s challenge by saying 'Fuck you man...'
Climbs to help Tracy and Lisa in a dangerous situation despite Tony's threats, uses playful rhymes to lighten the mood.
Pulls both girls to him once inside, indicating protective and caring behavior.
Calmly negotiating and diffusing a dangerous standoff with an armed Tony by skillfully engaging the women inside, ultimately gaining safe passage.
Uses playful rhymes to lighten the tense situation, showing quick thinking and confidence under pressure.
Uses a Nautilus machine in his office to push his body to its considerable limits, showing discipline and drive.
Keeps focused on his work by checking with his assistant about important documents before a meeting.
Maintains professionalism by welcoming his assistant despite being interrupted during intense exercise.
Attempts to charm or distract his assistant with casual banter and a dinner invitation during work hours, which might be seen as mixing professionalism with personal interest.
Invites Pam warmly to dinner.
Responds to Pam's refusal with persistence and teasing sarcasm ('I wasn’t aware - Ms. Perkins - that you shat at all.'), showing a lack of respect and friendliness.
Responds to Pam's refusal to have dinner with persistence and quick-witted verbal retort.
Clenches at a clichéd defense, but immediately escalates the interaction confidently and humorously.
Handles the phone ringing by immediately answering without breaking rhythm, showing multitasking ability and focus.
Confidently takes lead in climb, expresses determination to succeed.
Confidently decides to dyno the whole pitch without using pitons, asserting ownership of the climb.
Dismisses established safety norms by choosing a zero piton wall approach, risking unusual climbing methods.
Suggests moving camp to a safer location after recognizing danger, and encourages others to keep in touch for safety.
Engages in sarcastic, dismissive remarks about others (e.g. calling Clayborn 'the Donald Trump of the North West').
Questions Harold's odd behavior with a hint of concern and diagnostic curiosity ('Let's see now --- High altitude euphoria? No. Protein deficiency? I don’t think so. Not yet. Hereditary insanity?')
Analyzes Harold's behavior logically, considering possible medical or psychological causes (high altitude euphoria, protein deficiency, hereditary insanity).
Picks up the rope and identifies the path leading from their tent to the snow cave, aiding in the rescue effort.
Shakes head when asked about the other tent, indicating uncertainty or lack of information but immediately suggests starting digging, showing decisiveness.
Comforts Harold who is distraught, demonstrating emotional intelligence and leadership under stress.
Engages Clayborn in a thoughtful conversation about team gaps and potential replacements, indicating strategic thinking.
Dresses more flamboyantly compared to the serious tone of the older veteran, which could suggest less professionalism in appearance.

Expresses deep personal motivation and clarity of purpose about climbing K2.
Waves a piece of paper angrily in a legal meeting, questioning why he was not fully informed.

Insists on moving forward with the plan despite opposition, demonstrates determination and confidence.

About to forcefully barge into Trenton’s office without apparent caution.

Makes a teasing comment to Dallas about going down the crevasse.
Shows impatience or possibly frustration by asking if they are camping here or not.

Holds the rope taut with others to successfully arrest a falling climber, contributing to a life-saving effort.
Asks if they are camping or continuing despite the obvious fatigue and tension among the porters, indicating situational awareness.
Engages in light banter about going down the crevasse, which risks provoking unnecessary tension in a fragile situation.
Consults collaboratively with Clayborn about fixed ropes and logistics, showing engagement and teamwork.
Makes a practical joke or friendly warning telling Harold to take off his wedding ring before the avalanche.
Points on the map and asks a relevant strategic question about fixed ropes to Camp Four.
Advises Harold to take off his wedding ring just before a big avalanche.

Asks if everyone gets an equal shot at the summit, indicating fairness and concern for teammates.

Leads the climb with determination despite exhaustion, uses two-way radio to maintain connection with base and coordinate team efforts.
Focuses intensely on the view and task at hand, while others are too exhausted to notice; shows no explicit interaction or concern for others' condition in this excerpt.
Immediately takes the lead in climbing a difficult vertical ice chimney without hesitation.
Successfully reaches the top first despite being exhausted, demonstrating physical and mental stamina.
Uses two-way radio to maintain communication with Base Camp, showing awareness and responsibility.
Focuses on the view and communicates readiness to proceed while others are too exhausted to respond.
Offers to lay the ropes to Camp Three by himself so others can rest.

Engages in dialogue that acknowledges harsh truths (e.g., admitting 'Yeah, but at least I don’t mind telling the truth about it.').

Suggests leaving all heavy equipment behind to travel light and move quickly, indicating practical and strategic thinking.

Carries only the bare minimum equipment necessary for a day's climbing, indicating efficient preparation and understanding of the climb's demands.

Encourages Harold to go on ahead to have his own big moment on the mountain.

Unhooks and secures a dazed companion to the slope and forces him to drink, showing practical survival skill and care.
Lies to a companion to keep him alert and motivated despite severe injury and risk.
Leads and guides a seriously injured companion safely around the crevasse with clear instructions and encouragement.
Injects adrenaline into delirious Harold to revive him and encourages him to continue despite exhaustion.
Expresses uncertainty about exact location but remains supportive and reassuring to Harold.
Ropes himself to Harold despite difficult circumstances; alternates leading and supporting Harold physically.
Fashions a sledge to carry injured Harold, showing care and resourcefulness.
Sometimes leads Harold while dragging him along, sometimes staggers on feet despite difficult conditions.
Throws out some items from pack and organizes others into zip-flaps, then fashions a sledge to carry injured Harold.
Laboriously drags Harold's sledge down the slope despite worsening conditions and his own physical decline.
Stops and trudges back to check on unconscious Harold, showing care and awareness of the situation.
Uses humor and imagination to keep morale up despite dire conditions.
Listens keenly for signs of Harold’s breath despite harsh wind noise, demonstrating attentiveness and survival awareness.
Fires a rocket flare to signal for help while facing worsening weather conditions.
Dances, points, waves excitedly to get helicopter’s attention to rescue Harold.
Urges Harold to stop being stubborn and to share the moment of victory, asking for 'one little heart beat.'
Unlashes Harold from the sledge, supports him to stand, and raises his arm in a victory salute together.
